ground_truth: Don has already reached the second floor and is hurrying down the stairs, the fur coat over his arm, not paying any attention to Helen, and is just coming from it. He walks down the street about ten steps when Helen comes up to him, but Don disregards her and tries to go on. Helen overtakes him and blocks his way, but he continues on. Helen stands looking after him for a moment, then turns angrily and proceeds toward the pawn shop where the pawn broker has put her coat on a hanger and is brushing it. Helen enters, very matter-of-fact. In another scene, Don is at the desk writing on the second page of a letter, with a revolver beside him, ending with, "But amid all the grimness can we share one little joke, dear Wick: I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." He puts down the pen, stands the letter conspicuously on the desk, picks up the revolver, gets the cartridges from the drawer, and loads the gun. Having been out in the rain, his hair is still a little damp, and he walks into the bathroom. Don stands and looks at himself in the mirror with the gun in his hand, notices the unbuttoned points of his collar, and with a rueful smile at the funny timing of his urge for tidiness, buttons one. As he is buttoning the second, he hears a sound from outside, becomes startled, and puts the gun into the empty wash bowl. The door is being opened and Helen, breathing hard from her race to get there, enters with rain on her hair and face, and a wet dress. Don comes from the bathroom as Helen stands staring at him, wiping the rain from her face, and maybe some tears too. She looks around desperately and sees the gun reflected in the shaving mirror. Before she can step toward it, Don returns with a scarf. Helen goes to the umbrella stand and takes out a bottle, puts down the raincoat and scarf, and goes to the kitchen for a glass. Don picks up the raincoat and scarf, bends down for a kiss, while Helen stands looking at him and holds out the glass. She turns, runs into the bathroom, and picks up the gun with Don following her. Helen holds the gun behind her while Don half pushes, half leads her into the entrance hall. Overcome by a wave of weakness, he sags against the door, then goes and opens it.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Don has previously arrived at the subsequent level and is rushing down the steps, the pelt coat over his limb, not giving any heed to Helen, and is just departing from it. He strides down the road about ten paces when Helen approaches him, but Don ignores her and attempts to proceed. Helen catches up with him and obstructs his path, but he continues onward. Helen stands gazing after him for a moment, then turns angrily and advances toward the pawn store where the pawnbroker has placed her coat on a hanger and is brushing it. Helen enters, very pragmatic. In another scene, Don is at the counter inscribing on the second sheet of a note, with a pistol beside him, concluding with, "But amid all the severity can we share one little jest, dear Wick: I did complete something, didn’t I? Farewell." He sets down the quill, places the note prominently on the desk, picks up the pistol, retrieves the shells from the drawer, and loads the firearm. Having been in the drizzle, his hair is still slightly moist, and he walks into the lavatory. Don stands and gazes at himself in the looking glass with the firearm in his hand, notices the unfastened points of his collar, and with a rueful grin at the amusing timing of his urge for neatness, fastens one. As he is fastening the second, he hears a noise from outside, becomes startled, and places the firearm into the vacant wash basin. The door is being opened and Helen, panting from her sprint to get there, enters with moisture on her hair and visage, and a damp garment. Don comes from the lavatory as Helen stands staring at him, wiping the moisture from her visage, and maybe some sobs too. She glances around frantically and sees the firearm reflected in the shaving mirror. Before she can step toward it, Don returns with a muffler. Helen goes to the umbrella holder and takes out a flask, puts down the raincoat and muffler, and goes to the kitchen for a goblet. Don picks up the raincoat and muffler, bends down for a peck, while Helen stands gazing at him and holds out the goblet. She turns, dashes into the lavatory, and picks up the firearm with Don following her. Helen holds the firearm behind her while Don half pushes, half guides her into the entryway. Overcome by a surge of debility, he droops against the portal, then goes and opens it.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Don has already reached the second floor and is hurrying down the stairs, the fur coat over his arm, not paying any attention to Helen, and is just coming from it. The street is walked down by him about ten steps when Helen comes up to him, but he disregards her and tries to go on. He is overtaken by Helen, and she blocks his way, but he continues on. After him, Helen stands looking for a moment, then turns angrily and proceeds toward the pawn shop where the pawn broker is putting her coat on a hanger and brushing it. Very matter-of-fact, she enters. In another scene, Don is writing on the second page of a letter at the desk, with a revolver beside him, ending with, "But amid all the grimness can we share one little joke, dear Wick: I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." The pen is put down by him, and the letter is stood conspicuously on the desk, as he picks up the revolver, gets the cartridges from the drawer, and loads the gun. Having been out in the rain, his hair is still a little damp, and the bathroom is walked into by him. He stands and looks at himself in the mirror with the gun in his hand, notices the unbuttoned points of his collar, and with a rueful smile at the funny timing of his urge for tidiness, one is buttoned by him. As the second is being buttoned, a sound from outside is heard by him, he becomes startled, and into the empty wash bowl, the gun is put. The door is opened, and Helen, breathing hard from her race to get there, enters with rain on her hair and face, and a wet dress. From the bathroom comes Don, as she stands staring at him, wiping the rain from her face, and maybe some tears too. Around desperately she looks and the gun reflected in the shaving mirror is seen by her. Before she can step toward it, he returns with a scarf. The umbrella stand is gone to by Helen, and she takes out a bottle, puts down the raincoat and scarf, and a glass is gone to for in the kitchen. The raincoat and scarf are picked up by him, and for a kiss, he bends down, while she stands looking at him and holds out the glass. She turns, the bathroom is run into by her, and the gun is picked up with him following her. She holds the gun behind her while half pushing, half leading, she is by him into the entrance hall. Overcome by a wave of weakness, against the door, he sags, then goes and opens it.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Don reaches the second floor and hurries down the stairs, holding a fur coat and ignoring Helen. He walks ten steps before Helen overtakes him and blocks his path, but he pushes on. Helen watches him leave and heads toward the pawn shop, where the broker is brushing her coat. Helen enters calmly. In another scene, Don writes a letter at the desk with a revolver beside him, ending with, "But amid all the grimness can we share one little joke, dear Wick: I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." He places the letter visibly, loads the gun, and enters the bathroom. His damp hair from the rain highlights the unbuttoned points of his collar, which he buttons with a rueful smile. Startled by an outside noise, he places the gun in the wash bowl. Helen, out of breath and wet from the rain, enters. Don emerges as Helen wipes rain and perhaps tears away. She sees the gun's reflection in the mirror. Before she can approach it, Don returns with a scarf. Helen moves to the umbrella stand, grabs a bottle, sets down the scarf and raincoat, and retrieves a glass from the kitchen. Don picks up the items and bends for a kiss while Helen offers the glass. She races to the bathroom and grabs the gun, with Don following. Helen hides the gun as Don leads her to the entrance hall. Overcome, he leans against the door before opening it.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Don rushes downstairs, a fur coat over his arm, ignoring Helen. Ten steps down the street, Helen confronts him, but he continues. She angrily heads to the pawn shop, where the broker is brushing her coat. Meanwhile, Don writes a letter with a revolver beside him, noting, "I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." He loads the gun, damp from rain, and goes to the bathroom. Staring at his reflection, he tidies his collar. Startled by a noise, he leaves the gun in the wash bowl. Helen, wet from rain, enters exhausted. Seeing the gun in the mirror, she grabs a bottle, fetches a glass, and offers it to Don. She takes the gun to the bathroom, with Don following. She hides it, and he escorts her to the entrance, collapsing against the door before opening it.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
Don has already made his way to the second floor and is now hastily making his way down the stairs, carrying the fur coat draped over his arm. He is completely oblivious to Helen, and it seems he is just emerging from the staircase. As he strides purposefully down the street, he has barely taken about ten steps when Helen approaches him determinedly. Despite her presence, Don chooses to disregard her and makes an effort to continue on his way. Helen, however, is not easily deterred; she manages to catch up with him and purposefully blocks his path, but he resolutely continues moving forward. Helen stands there momentarily, watching him as he walks away. With frustration evident in her demeanor, she turns abruptly and heads toward the pawn shop. Inside the shop, the pawnbroker has already hung her coat on a hanger and is carefully brushing it, preparing it for display or sale. Helen enters the shop, her expression and manner very matter-of-fact and businesslike.

In a separate scene, we find Don seated at a desk, deeply engrossed in writing on the second page of a letter. A revolver lies ominously beside him, casting a shadow on the intentions behind his written words. He concludes the letter with an enigmatic line, "But amid all the grimness, can we share one little joke, dear Wick: I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." With a slight sense of finality, he sets the pen down, placing the letter prominently upright on the desk for all to see. He then picks up the revolver, retrieves cartridges from the drawer, and methodically loads the gun. Having recently been out in the rain, his hair still bears traces of dampness, giving him a slightly disheveled appearance as he makes his way into the bathroom. Standing in front of the mirror, Don takes a moment to reflect on his image and notices the unbuttoned points of his collar. With a rueful smile and a sense of irony at the timing of his sudden desire for tidiness, he buttons one point and is in the process of buttoning the second when he is startled by a sound from outside. Immediately, he places the gun into the empty wash bowl as the door begins to open. Helen, breathless from her hurried race to reach him, enters the room, with rainwater glistening on her hair and face, and her dress visibly wet from the downpour.

Don emerges from the bathroom just as Helen stands there, staring at him intently, wiping not only the rain but perhaps also a few stray tears from her face. Her eyes dart around the room desperately, and she catches sight of the gun reflected in the shaving mirror. Before she can make a move toward it, Don returns holding a scarf. Helen quickly goes to the umbrella stand, retrieves a bottle, and then heads to the kitchen in search of a glass. In the meantime, Don picks up the raincoat and scarf, bending down to offer her a kiss. Helen, however, remains standing, looking at him intently as she holds out the glass. Abruptly, she turns and rushes into the bathroom, retrieving the gun with Don close behind her. Helen conceals the gun behind her back as Don half guides, half pushes her into the entrance hall. Suddenly overcome by a wave of weakness, he leans heavily against the door for support before eventually moving to open it.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
Don has already made his way to the second floor of the building and is now rapidly descending the stairs, with the fur coat elegantly draped over his arm. He is utterly oblivious to Helen at this moment, and it appears he is just emerging from the dimly lit staircase. As he strides purposefully down the bustling street, he has barely taken about ten steps when Helen approaches him with determined resolve. Despite her presence, Don chooses to ignore her entirely and makes a concerted effort to continue on his determined path. Helen, however, is not one to be easily deterred; she manages to catch up with him and firmly positions herself in his path, aiming to block his progress. Nevertheless, he resolutely continues moving forward. Helen stands there for a brief moment, watching him as he walks resolutely away. With frustration clearly etched in her demeanor, she turns abruptly and heads determinedly toward the nearby pawn shop. Inside the shop, the pawnbroker has already hung her coat neatly on a hanger and is meticulously brushing it, preparing it for either display or sale. Helen enters the shop with an expression and manner that are very much matter-of-fact and businesslike.

In a separate scene, we find Don seated at a desk, deeply engrossed in the task of writing on the second page of a letter. A revolver lies ominously beside him, casting a shadow over the intentions behind the words he has penned. He concludes the letter with an enigmatic line, "But amid all the grimness, can we share one little joke, dear Wick: I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." With a slight sense of finality, he sets the pen down, placing the folded letter prominently upright on the desk for all to see. He then picks up the revolver, retrieves shiny cartridges from the drawer, and methodically begins to load the gun. Having recently been out in the rain, his hair still bears traces of dampness, giving him a slightly disheveled appearance as he makes his way into the bathroom. Standing in front of the bathroom mirror, Don takes a moment to reflect on his own image and notices the unbuttoned points of his collar. With a rueful smile and a sense of irony at the timing of his sudden desire for tidiness, he buttons one point and is in the process of buttoning the second when he is startled by an unexpected sound from outside. Immediately, he quickly places the gun into the empty wash bowl just as the door begins to open. Helen, breathless from her hurried race to reach him, enters the room, with rainwater glistening on her hair and face, and her dress visibly wet from the downpour.

Don emerges from the bathroom just as Helen stands there, staring intently at him, wiping not only the rain but perhaps also a few stray tears from her face. Her eyes dart around the room in a desperate search, and she catches sight of the gun reflected in the shaving mirror. Before she can make a move toward it, Don returns holding a delicate scarf. Helen quickly goes to the umbrella stand, retrieves a hidden bottle, and then heads swiftly to the kitchen in search of a glass. In the meantime, Don picks up the raincoat and scarf, bending down to offer her a gentle kiss. Helen, however, remains standing, looking at him intently as she holds out the glass. Abruptly, she turns and rushes purposefully into the bathroom, retrieving the gun with Don close behind her. Helen conceals the gun behind her back as Don half guides, half pushes her gently into the entrance hall. Suddenly overcome by a wave of weakness, he leans heavily against the door for support before eventually gathering the strength to move and open it.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Don has already made his way up to the second floor and is now rapidly descending the stairs, the weight of the fur coat draped over his arm. His focus is fixed ahead, completely disregarding Helen, who is approaching from the opposite direction. As he exits the building, he strides down the street, counting out about ten determined steps before Helen catches up to him. Don, however, remains indifferent to her presence, his mind set on moving forward. Undeterred, Helen speeds up to overtake him, strategically positioning herself to obstruct his path, but Don is resolute in his intent and continues on his way. Left in his wake, Helen pauses momentarily, watching his retreating figure with a mix of emotions clouding her face. Frustrated and angry, she pivots on her heel and makes her way toward the pawn shop. Upon her arrival, she observes the pawnbroker who has already placed her coat on a hanger and is now brushing it with brisk, methodical movements. Helen enters the shop with an air of dispassionate resolve. Meanwhile, in another scene, Don is settled at a desk, diligently writing on the second page of a letter while a revolver lies ominously beside him. He meticulously inscribes the words, "But amid all the grimness can we share one little joke, dear Wick: I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." Completing the letter, he deliberately places the pen down and positions the letter prominently on the desk before reaching for the revolver. Opening a nearby drawer, he retrieves the cartridges and methodically loads the gun. His hair, slightly damp from the rain outside, clings to his head as he moves into the bathroom. Standing before the mirror, Don scrutinizes his reflection, the gun still firmly in his grasp. He notices the casual disarray of his unbuttoned collar points and, with a wry smile at the odd timing of his sudden need for order, begins to button one. As he is about to button the second, an unexpected noise from outside startles him, causing him to hastily place the gun into the empty wash bowl. The door creaks open, and Helen bursts in, breathless from her hurried race to reach him, rain streaming down her hair and face, her dress thoroughly soaked. Don emerges from the bathroom just as Helen stands there, processing the scene, her face a mixture of rain and perhaps a few stray tears. She scans the room in desperation, her gaze finally landing on the gun's reflection in the shaving mirror. Before she can make a move towards it, Don re-enters the room, now holding a scarf. Helen decisively approaches the umbrella stand, retrieves a hidden bottle, sets down her raincoat and the scarf, and heads to the kitchen in search of a glass. Meanwhile, Don, picking up the discarded raincoat and scarf, bends down for a moment of affection, aiming to plant a kiss, while Helen stands before him, her expression inscrutable, extending the glass toward him. Abruptly, she spins around and dashes into the bathroom, seizing the gun just as Don trails closely behind her. Helen clutches the gun protectively behind her back while Don, in a state of emotional turmoil, both nudges and guides her toward the entrance hall with a mixture of insistence and gentleness. He suddenly finds himself overwhelmed by a wave of weariness, causing him to slump against the door momentarily before mustering the strength to go and open it.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description:
Don hurries down the stairs, ignoring Helen as he exits the building with a fur coat draped over his arm. Walking down the street, he tries to ignore Helen as she catches up and blocks his path, but continues on as she stands watching him leave. Frustrated, Helen turns and heads to the pawn shop, where the broker is brushing her coat. She enters, appearing very matter-of-fact.

In another scene, Don sits at a desk writing a letter, with a revolver beside him. He concludes the letter with a grim joke, places it prominently on the desk, and loads the gun after retrieving cartridges from a drawer. Damp from the rain, he moves to the bathroom, examines himself in the mirror, and starts to button his collar with a rueful smile before being startled by a sound outside. He quickly places the gun in the wash bowl as Helen, breathless and wet from the rain, enters and wipes her face. 

Don emerges from the bathroom as Helen, distraught, notices the gun's reflection. Before she can reach for it, Don returns with a scarf. Helen heads to the umbrella stand, retrieves a bottle, and goes to the kitchen for a glass. Don picks up the raincoat and scarf, leans in for a kiss, and Helen hands him the glass. She then rushes to the bathroom, seizes the gun, and Don follows her. Helen conceals the gun behind her, and Don gently guides her to the entrance hall. Overcome with weakness, he leans against the door momentarily before opening it.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Don has already reached the second floor of the old apartment building, which is known for its narrow, creaky stairs, and is hurrying down the stairs, the fur coat, a lavish mink he picked up from an upscale shop, over his arm, not paying any attention to Helen, and is just coming from it. He walks down the street about ten steps on the bustling downtown sidewalk when Helen comes up to him, but Don disregards her and tries to go on. Helen, who is wearing a look of determination, overtakes him and blocks his way, but he continues on, dodging past her with a practiced agility. Helen stands looking after him for a moment, then turns angrily and proceeds toward the pawn shop, a dimly lit establishment known for its discreet transactions, where the pawnbroker has put her coat on a hanger and is brushing it with care as if examining a valuable antique. Helen enters, very matter-of-fact, despite the tension in the air. In another scene, Don is at the desk in his study, surrounded by stacks of unfinished manuscripts, writing on the second page of a letter, with a revolver, an old family heirloom with an intricate design on the handle, beside him, ending with, "But amid all the grimness can we share one little joke, dear Wick: I did finish something, didn’t I? Goodbye." He puts down the pen, stands the letter conspicuously on the desk, picks up the revolver, gets the cartridges from the drawer, and loads the gun with a steady hand. Having been out in the rain, his hair is still a little damp, and he walks into the bathroom, which features a cracked, aging mirror. Don stands and looks at himself in the mirror with the gun in his hand, notices the unbuttoned points of his collar, and with a rueful smile at the funny timing of his urge for tidiness, buttons one. As he is buttoning the second, he hears a sound from outside, becomes startled, and puts the gun into the empty porcelain wash bowl. The door is being opened and Helen, breathing hard from her race to get there, enters with rain on her hair and face, and a wet dress clinging to her frame. Don comes from the bathroom as Helen stands staring at him, wiping the rain from her face, and maybe some tears too, the storm outside mirroring the turmoil within her. She looks around desperately and sees the gun reflected in the shaving mirror with its tarnished silver frame. Before she can step toward it, Don returns with a scarf, an old gift from Helen. Helen goes to the umbrella stand and takes out a bottle, the one she knows Don has hidden there in moments of despair, puts down the raincoat and scarf, and goes to the kitchen for a glass. Don picks up the raincoat and scarf, bends down for a kiss, while Helen stands looking at him and holds out the glass with an expression of both defiance and hope. She turns, runs into the bathroom, and picks up the gun with Don following her, a blend of fear and urgency in his steps. Helen holds the gun behind her while Don half pushes, half leads her into the entrance hall. Overcome by a wave of weakness, he sags against the door, then goes and opens it, letting in the scent of rain and the distant sounds of city life at night.

Helen goes to the umbrella stand and takes out a bottle puts down the raincoat and scarf and goes to the kitchen for a glass. Don picks up the raincoat and scarf bends down for a kiss while Helen stands looking at him and holds out the glass. She turns runs into the bathroom and picks up the gun with Don following her. Helen holds the gun behind her while Don half pushes half leads her into the entrance hall Overcome by a wave of weakness he sags against the door then goes and opens it.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Don has already reached the second floor and is hurrying down the stairs the fur coat over his arm not paying any attention to Helen and is just coming from it. He walks down the street about ten steps when Helen comes up to him but Don disregards her and tries to go on. Helen overtakes him and blocks his way but he continues on. She turns runs into the bathroom and picks up the gun with Don following her. Helen holds the gun behind her while Don half pushes half leads her into the entrance hall Overcome by a wave of weakness he sags against the door then goes and opens it.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Larry has already climbed the ladder and is sprinting up the hill, the woolen sweater over his shoulder, not noticing Marge, and is just leaving the hillside. He skips across the meadow about ten paces when Marge catches up to him, but Larry ignores her and attempts to continue. Marge surpasses him and blocks his trail, but he persists. Marge stands observing him for a moment, then spins frustratedly and strides toward the antique store where the shopkeeper has placed her sweater on a mannequin and is polishing it. Marge enters, very nonchalant. In a different scene, Larry is at the counter scribbling on the second sheet of a postcard, with a wrench beside him, concluding with, "But amid all the chaos can we share one little laugh, dear Sam: I did complete something, didn’t I? Farewell." He sets down the pencil, props the postcard visibly on the counter, picks up the wrench, retrieves the bolts from the cupboard, and assembles the tool. Having been out in the drizzle, his beard is still somewhat damp, and he strolls into the basement. Larry stands and gazes at himself in the window with the wrench in his hand, notices the untied ends of his shoelace, and with a wry grin at the odd timing of his impulse for neatness, ties one. As he is tying the second, he hears a noise from inside, becomes alarmed, and places the wrench into the empty flowerpot. The window is being opened and Marge, panting from her dash to arrive there, enters with dew on her hat and jacket, and a moist apron. Larry emerges from the basement as Marge stands gaping at him, dabbing the dew from her jacket, and maybe some raindrops too. She glances around urgently and spots the wrench reflected in the picture frame. Before she can move toward it, Larry returns with a hat. Marge goes to the basket and takes out a notebook, places down the jacket and hat, and goes to the pantry for a mug. Larry picks up the jacket and hat, leans down for an embrace, while Marge stands watching him and hands over the mug. She turns, dashes into the basement, and picks up the wrench with Larry trailing her. Marge conceals the wrench behind her while Larry half nudges, half guides her into the lounge. Overcome by a wave of fatigue, he collapses against the wall, then moves and closes it.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Don, carrying a fur coat, ignores Helen as he hurriedly leaves a building. Helen follows, tries to block him, but he continues on. Frustrated, she heads to a pawn shop to retrieve her coat. Meanwhile, Don writes a farewell letter at a desk beside a revolver, ending with a dark joke. He loads the gun, and while adjusting his collar in the bathroom mirror, hears a noise and hides the weapon. Helen enters, drenched from rain and likely tears. Observing the situation, she spots the gun's reflection, but before she can act, Don reemerges with a scarf. She retrieves a bottle and glass, signaling her intentions. As Don bends for a kiss, she runs to grab the gun. Don follows her, and, after a struggle, they end up in the entrance hall. Overcome, Don leans against the door before opening it.
